oneOf.title: Image Composite
oneOf.description: The imageComposite asset is a container of other image assets that are to be composited on top of one another or need to be explicitly grouped together. It can contain only image assets. A simple example of this would be for an animation of a light bulb turning on, or a stack of documents than fans out. A single visual concept that needs to be built of of several images. To render the light bulb example animation there may need to be several parts of the light bulb (on state, off state, light rays(5)) that need to be semantically grouped together as light bulb parts. NOTE: at the moment there is no default rendering spec for this asset. It is used for custom roles, as most image composites are for specific cases.

defaultSnippets.label: Image Composite
defaultSnippets.description: The imageComposite asset is a container of other image assets that are to be composited on top of one another or need to be explicitly grouped together. It can contain only image assets. A simple example of this would be for an animation of a light bulb turning on, or a stack of documents than fans out. A single visual concept that needs to be built of of several images. To render the light bulb example animation there may need to be several parts of the light bulb (on state, off state, light rays(5)) that need to be semantically grouped together as light bulb parts. NOTE: at the moment there is no default rendering spec for this asset. It is used for custom roles, as most image composites are for specific cases.

It is expected that these assets will be rendered together in the order as they appear in the composite.

metaData.description: The following metaData/roles are supported on actions -- primary: A primary action, secondary: An action with less visual weight, for secondary actions, tertiary: An action with even less visual weight than secondary. Usually used for actions within content as apposed to actions within navigation, upsell: Indicates a user's acceptance of an upsell, back: Brings the user back to the previous step in a player flow, link: Indicates that the action should be rendered as a link (rather than a button), inline-link: Indicates that the action should be rendered as an inline link. This is similar to link however it is intended to render along with text and flow with the text, much like an HTML hyperlink would, or as a composite with a link would. Note that different players may render link and 'inline-link` the same, or differently, as appropriate for the platform.

confirmation.description: Action assets can also contain an (optional) confirmation property. Actions that contain a confirmation property will require user-confirmation before the action can be executed. The player will present the user with a confirmation and only execute the action if the affirmative choice is made. This is ideal for actions that do destructive things, like delete data or clear values. A confirmation can be used as an alert if it has only the affirmativeLabel (no negativeLabel). Optionally the confirmation can have a title.

oneOf.title: Deck
oneOf.description: The overall idea is that you have a deck asset that contains multiple card assets. One card asset is shown to the user at a time. At the moment decks can have two ways of navigating through the cards: carousel or tree. By default the tree navigation will will be enabled and will listen for special application/card link click events to drill down into cards. Each card you jump to will be added to a stack and a bread crumb navigation will appear which can lead you back where you came from. The order in which the cards are defined does not have any navigational impact apart from where the deck starts. By default the deck will start at the first defined card, unless a start ID is specified within the card metaData section. The second navigational structure is the carousel which respects the order in which the cards are defined. It will also render the first card by default unless the start ID is defined in the metaData, however the navigational wise we have both forward and back links which will just navigate iteratively through the cards. The application/card links within the carousel view will also work, however unlike the drill down paradigm, they will behave as a jump to.

By default the tree navigation will will be enabled and will listen for special application/card link click events to drill down into cards. Each card you jump to will be added to a stack and a bread crumb navigation will appear which can lead you back where you came from. The order in which the cards are defined does not have any navigational impact apart from where the deck starts. By default the deck will start at the first defined card, unless a start ID is specified within the card metaData section. The second navigational structure is the carousel which respects the order in which the cards are defined. It will also render the first card by default unless the start ID is defined in the metaData, however the navigational wise we have both forward and back links which will just navigate iteratively through the cards. The application/card links within the carousel view will also work, however unlike the drill down paradigm, they will behave as a jump to.

oneOf.title: Multi Input
oneOf.description: MultiInput assets are specific type of data collection where user is allowed to enter multiple instances of a structured data type with small number of fields. The MultiInput asset is usually rendered as a two-dimensional table on a large form factor device, with rows for unique instances of the structured data type and columns for individual fields within each instance. However, on small form factor devices, each instance of the structured data type can be rendered as a separate block of input fields. The table is expandable as new instance is being added to the table.

However, on small form factor devices, each instance of the structured data type can be rendered as a separate block of input fields. The table is expandable as new instance is being added to the table.

oneOf.title: File Input
oneOf.description: Conceptually, file-based input is similar to other input from the user. Instead of coming from the user's keyboard, this input comes from the user's filesystem. Like other inputs, we specify the data model(s) to bind to. Under the current proposal, the file's content is never set directly to a model. Instead, it is sent to a web service for processing, where the relevant data is extracted and returned to the Player, which sets it into the bound data models.

Like other inputs, we specify the data model(s) to bind to. Under the current proposal, the file's content is never set directly to a model. Instead, it is sent to a web service for processing, where the relevant data is extracted and returned to the Player, which sets it into the bound data models.

oneOf.title: Tabular Data
oneOf.description: TabularData assets are more specific type of data collection where user is presented with a two-dimensional array of text assets (think spreadsheets) or field assets (input or choice). The TabularData is usually rendered as a two-dimensional table on large form factor devices, with rows and columns corresponding to each dimension. However, on small form factor devices, rows or columns can be rendered as separate blocks of information. By design, tabularData has fixed dimension for the two-dimensional arrays. Thus it cannot grow or shrink in number of rows, which is different than multiInput.

defaultSnippets.label: Tabular Data

However, on small form factor devices, rows or columns can be rendered as separate blocks of information. By design, tabularData has fixed dimension for the two-dimensional arrays. Thus it cannot grow or shrink in number of rows, which is different than multiInput.

oneOf.description:
This role will make the entire tabularData structure readonly for summary purpose. It allows special visual rendering different than input fields.
E.g. in ACA penalty explanation screen, monthly penalty amount is a single row in tabularData and rendered as a 12x1 grid (large form factor) or 4x3 grid (small form factor).

This role allows special visual rendering different than input fields.
E.g. In the W2 summary of tips screen, the tips are summarized in tabularData and rendered as a 4x2 grid with a footer row calculating the total. The numbers in the second column are right justified (instead of left justified as they would be with a non-specified role), and the whole table is centered.

oneOf.title: Landing Table Section
oneOf.description: LandingTableSection is an asset that is one of the values of the LandingTable asset. This asset describes the type of content that is to be displayed in each row of the landing table. The section also contains a list of values composed of TopicItem assets to describe any individual topics that a user can address that fall under the category described in a LandingTableSection. This asset can also be used to launch a composite topic which can address all of its sub-topics. This is used to allow a user to visit all pieces of content that are relevant to the topic described by the LandingTableSection. For example: in a LandingTable describing a user's tax situation, a LandingTableSection showing a user's common income could have a button that walks the user through topics such as a 1099-G, 1099-MISC, and 1099-K. These topics can also be launched individually through use of a TopicItem asset specified in the values section of the LandingTableSection.

oneOf.title: Gateway
oneOf.description: Defines a view that is used as a gateway to a new (sub) topic. This view type presents the user with a brief introduction to the topic it is in front of, and asks them if they want to visit it.

id.description: A unique identifier for the asset, used for automation testing and runtime tracing. Must be alphanumeric (beginning with alpha), underscore or dash only.

type.description: Name of the supported asset types, can be image, text, composite, etc.

listeners.description: Views can specify that certain expressions are executed based on events.

validation.description: Custom validations at the view level (also known as cross-field validations) are typically verified when any field on the page is interacted with as well as when the user attempts to navigate from the current view.

title.description: Top level title for the view.

subtitle.description: Displayed below the top level title, typically in smaller text with a different color.

titleImage.description: Contains an image asset that iconifies the topic.
titleImage.title: Image Assets

tip.description: Below the title but above the main content, typically used for important information called out with special styling.

primaryInfo.description: Where the main content goes, this should be the body of the page.

additionalInfo.description: Below the main content but above the actions, typically used for important links at the bottom of a view.

actions.description: Actions for navigating in between views.

items.title: Action Choice
items.description: User actions can be represented in several places. Each view typically has one or more actions that allow the user to navigate away from that view. In addition, several asset types can have actions that apply to that asset only.

role.description: A role assigned that gives it greater semantic meaning.

interactions.description: Assets that need to interact or coordinate with each other use the interactions property.

coveredForms.description: An array of text or composite assets that tell the user what tax-forms are filled-out with this section. There is also an optional label for the coveredForms.

label.title: Text Assets
label.description: A text asset or grouping of text assets.

coveredTopics.description: An array of text or composite assets that tell the user what tax-topics are covered in this section. There is also an optional label for the coveredTopics.

gatewayActions.description: Determines how the user can navigate away from the page. Gateway screen actions are extremely specific: there MUST be exactly two actions (positive and negative) and an optional prevAction. There is also a binding for the action (optional) and the value of that binding is set to 'true' if the positive action is selected, and 'false' if the negative action is selected.

affirmativeAction.description: An action that signifies the user accepts the gateway.

negativeAction.description: An action that signifies the user rejects the gateway.

prevAction.description: An action that signifies the user wants to go back the previous screen.

oneOf.title: Transition

transitions.description: Transitions tells the Transition to automatically load the next flow from the server

onComplete.description: onCompletion of a custom animation (or no animation if immediately)

onError.description: unImplemented placeholder for future error handling

onTimeout.description: unImplemented placeholder for future error handling

onPing.description: unImplemented placeholder for future error handling

myData.description: Contains an asset that represents all of the data pertinent to user.

landingTable.description: Contains a table that lists navigable topics that the user can jump to.

asset.title: Landing Table
asset.description: The LandingTable asset is used as an overview for a collection of content or a set of tasks set for a user to choose from and accomplish. The asset acts as a landing element, similar to web landing page. The assets purpose is to provide a one stop shop to view and enter subsections of content that lead to other pages and flows. The asset can also display the completion status of its content subsections. This asset acts as a parent asset to a collection of LandingTableSection assets, which describe the subsections available for the user to select from and complete.

defaultSnippets.label: Landing Table
defaultSnippets.description: The LandingTable asset is used as an overview for a collection of content or a set of tasks set for a user to choose from and accomplish. The asset acts as a landing element, similar to web landing page. The assets purpose is to provide a one stop shop to view and enter subsections of content that lead to other pages and flows. The asset can also display the completion status of its content subsections. This asset acts as a parent asset to a collection of LandingTableSection assets, which describe the subsections available for the user to select from and complete.

id.description: A unique identifier for the asset, used for automation testing and runtime tracing. Must be alphanumeric (beginning with alpha), underscore or dash only.

type.description: Name of the supported asset types, can be image, text, composite, etc.

applicability.description: An expressions that is used to determine if the asset should be visible or hidden. The expressions must result in either true or false, if true then the asset will be 'applicable' to the view rendering, if false it will be hidden and will not participate in any data validation or changes.

oneOf.description: Used when the landingTable includes information directly for a user. This can be used to implement the responsive MyStuff experience.

label.description: A text asset used as a heading column above the Landing Table content.

description.description: A text asset used as a sub-heading to the Landing Table content, if desired (stationary only, does not render on mobile).

values.description: an array of landingTableSections assets that will be rendered as individual sections within the Landing Table. Values may be empty, in which case the players may render a placeholder.

placeholder.description: (only applicable when using the `personalized` role): A string to display when the landingTable has no values.

binding.description: A model reference that indicates the ID of the section that is expanded, if any.

actions.description: Intended to support one action (ex: toggle to 'guide me').

items.title: Action Assets
items.description: An action asset or grouping of action assets

modifiers.description: A set of modifiers to customize the asset

icon_modifier.description: A modifier used to add or override an icon to an asset.

value.description: An identifier for the icon. If used alongside the metaData.ref property, this icon will be used as a fallback in case the external icon fails to load.

ref.description: A URL (relative or absolute) to an external icon image.

consent.description: This area can contain a blurb of text, a checkbox, or a group input to get consent from the user

schema.description: Schema specifies the data definition for all user data visible in the declarative content. It also includes field or type validation information so that a platform specific UI Player can perform error checks real-time when user enters the input data.

additionalProperties._comment: required ['type'] - type used to be required, needs attention

data.description: The current value of user data relevant to the experience (conforming to the Schema outlined above) is included in the response so the UX Player can mange an in-memory client-side data store for displaying current known data for review, binding data value to dynamic content, executing flow control logic based on the data field value, and retaining newly collected user data to send back to application services.

navigation.description: Navigation specifies the user interaction flow logic, which is used to determine the next unit of information to present to user upon receiving user actions from the current view. It uses a state machine diagram to model the interaction flow, with nodes representing the view units (or action units) and edges representing the transitions, and additional attachment for specifying conditions associated with each transition.

BEGIN.description: Which flow to start the player with.

^(?!(?:BEGIN)$).*$.description: A set of views and action that describe a complete flow.

startState.description: Which action or view to start the flow with.

onStart.description: The onStart property indicates expressions that should be evaluated at the start of a flow. The value of the property may be a string, an array of strings, or an object with an 'exp' property.

exp.description: An expression that executes special fuego flavored JS with functions that connect to Fuego.

END_done.description: An action the finishes the flow, often setting outcome: 'doneWithTopic'

!(startState|onStart|END_done).description: A possible state in a flow.

transitions.description: A map of state to an action or view.

messages.description: All the default validation messages for the base types.

metaData.description: MetaData for the whole document. This object is optional, contains data about where and how the mock is used.

FRFVersion.description: The version of the response format that this response conforms to. This is used by the Player to determine if it can be rendered, or if the application has to find another player that can handle it. If the Player is this version or later, it will render it. If this property is absent then the player will assume it can render the response.

visualGallery.description: You can add your mock to the Visual Gallery by adding the Visual Gallery JSON to your mock by adding it to the metaData node. It will be picked up next time the Visual Gallery generator is ran and the web page is updated.

wiki.description: The wiki link to the Fuego Schema definition.

xd.description: The link to the XD specification.

description.description: The name of what is being shown.

group.description: The name of the asset group it belongs to. (the group name will automatically generated if new).

versionCreated.description: The version number when it was created.

types.description: Custom types (not compound types, that's the schema section) can be defined in the types section of the JSON. In addition to being able to define new types, the built-in ones can be redefined.

errorsAndWarnings.description: Server-side validations. Each of the errors and warnings in this section are rendered by the player on initial page load, along with any page-level messaging. Each key in this object should be a binding which points to the invalid field. You can also use a query-style lookup to pinpoint specific instances of multi-copy models.

items.description: An object describing a validation error and it's associated ID.

oneOf.description: How the validation should be triggered.
